Warthin collection ARC.319Collection processed by Patricia GlowinskiThis collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.Brooklyn Historical SocietyCenter for Brooklyn History128 Pierrepont StreetBrooklyn 11201cbhreference@bklynlibrary.orgThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2023-03-22T20:42:44engDescribing Archives: A Content StandardMarch 2023
Revised by Dee Bowers to incorporate additional material
Brooklyn Historical Society
Virginia W. Warthin collection
Warthin, Virginia W.
ARC.319
0.04 Linear Feet in two folders.
circa 19th century The Virginia W. Warthin collection consists of 13 black-and-white images of late 19th century Brooklyn and Manhattan as well as two 1855 school attendance certificates from P.S. 6 awarded to family members of Warthin's. Prints by Accession 56
Conditions Governing Access
Open to researchers without restriction.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Virginia W. Warthin, 1990.
Arrangement
The collection is arranged into two folders by type.
Biographical note
Virginia W. Warthin (nee Whittier; 1912-1995) was the great granddaughter of James Eaton, a Brooklyn resident who owned land on Schermerhorn Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood. Her grandmother and great aunt were Virginia and Sarah Eaton who grew up in Brooklyn and attended public schools, including P.S. 6. In 1918, the family's land on Schermerhorn Street was taken by eminent domain on which the city built the Children's Court. The family then moved to Sidney Place, also in Brooklyn Heights. Virginia W. Warthin attended Brooklyn Friends School. She later married Thomas A. Warthin, a physician, and they had three sons. After retirement, the Warthins lived in Walpole, MA.
Other Finding Aids
Item level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library. Please consult library staff for more information.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
If digital surrogates exist, they should be used in place of the originals whenever possible.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Virginia W. Warthin collection, ARC.319, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.
Scope and Contents
The Virginia W. Warthin collection consists of 13 black-and-white images of late 19th century Brooklyn and Manhattan as well as two 1855 school attendance certificates from P.S. 6 awarded to family members of Warthin's. The collection includes one albumen print showing a street scene of the Blizzard of 1888 as seen from Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn Heights, as well as 12 halftone reproductions of photographs and illustrations of views of the Brooklyn waterfront looking towards the lower Manhattan cityscape; a view of the Louis Bossert and Son Box Factory building in Brooklyn; and views of 19th century skyscrapers and surrounding buildings in lower Manhattan. The two school attendance certificates were awarded to Virginia Eaton, Warthin's grandmother, and Sarah Eaton, Warthin's great aunt.
Conditions Governing Use
While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
Processing Information
This collections consists of accession V1990.048 as well as additional related found-in-collection material.
